original_poem:
hiver 3
– faut-il se situer au-dessus des choses prendre de la hauteur ou au-dessous tout en profondeur – il y a aussi la tentation d’être loin des choses comme pour trouver une issue car il n’est pas permis de demeurer en elles – alors nous sommes ici et là alors l’ajustement est une constante le sens de la justesse un naturel comme la solitude nécessaire c’est elle qui nous fait à la fin c’est toujours ce qu’il nous reste de meilleur – quelle fatigue cette vie à ce point faite de riens cela demande une concentration énorme une énergie invraisemblable mais chacun fait comme il peut ce qu’il peut pour donner matière et consistance à ce qui se présente
arriver simplement à vivre
de jour en jour
y voir certains jours plus clair d'autres jours gris gris blanc gris foncé de la couleur encore et encore
translated_poem:
winter 3
– must we be higher than things rise above them or be beneath them all the way down – there’s always the temptation to gain a little distance as if you could find a way out because you certainly can’t stay as is – therefore we’re here and there therefore the need to adjust is constant the sense of justice as natural as the necessary solitude that ultimately makes us what we are at the end it’s the best of what’s left for us – it’s a tiring life made largely of little things that require tremendous concentration unbelievable energy but everyone does what they can to give form and consistency to whatever comes along
to simply arrive at living
day after day
to see more clearly on certain days on others grey grey white dark grey color again and again
translated_by_TA:
Winter 3
– should we place ourselves above things, gaining height, or below them, going down deep? There is also the temptation to be far from things, as if to find a way out, because it is not permitted to remain within them. So we are here and there, so adjustment is a constant, the sense of rightness, a naturalness like the necessary solitude, it is what makes us, in the end, it is always the best that remains for us. How tiring this life is, made up of nothing, it requires enormous concentration, incredible energy, but everyone does what they can to give substance and substance to what presents itself.
Simply managing to live
day by day
Seeing some days more clearly, other days gray, gray, white, dark gray, color, again and again.

original_poem:
hiver 2
– sourire vu reçu du côté bleu de son tendre cœur sa voix toujours parvient à faire vibrer jusqu’à moi la vivante nuance de son visage sa claire lumière dans un prononcé acquiescement tout en douceur partagée bruit d’un souffle fleuve balancé aux hasards de notre attention disposée à s’immerger chaleur et courage nous retiennent
toucher au vif de la vie
par quoi tout le corps s’incarne
toucher au secret de notre impulsion –
la fatigue nous éloigne nous rapproche de nous-mêmes – parvenir jusqu’à soi
comme il nous est demandé comme jamais
translated_poem:
winter 2
– a smile noticed received from the blue side of his tender heart his voice always able to make the living nuance of his face vibrate all the way across to me clear light so gently shared sound of a breath a river balanced on the fate of our attention always willing to be submerged warmth and courage hold us
to touch the core of life
where the body comes to be
to get to the secret of our impulsion –
exhaustion takes us away and brings us back to ourselves
– to reach the self
as it is required from us as never before
translated_by_TA:
Winter 2
– smile seen received from the blue side of her tender heart her voice always manages to make the living nuance of her face vibrate to me her clear light in a pronounced acquiescence all in shared sweetness sound of a breath river balanced to the hazards of our attention ready to immerse itself warmth and courage hold us
touching the heart of life
by which the whole body is embodied
touching the secret of our impulse –
fatigue distances us brings us closer to ourselves – reaching oneself
as it is asked of us like never before

original_poem:
de natura rerum
lucrèce le savait:
ouvre le coffre,
tu verras, il est plein de neige
qui tourbillonne.
et parfois deux flocons
se rencontrent, s’unissent,
ou bien l’un se détourne, gracieusement
dans son peu de mort.
d’où vient qu’il fasse clair
dans quelques mots
quand l’un n’est que la nuit,
l’autre, qu’un rêve ?
d’où viennent ces deux ombres
qui vont, riant,
et l’une emmitouflée
d’une laine rouge ?
translated_poem:
de natura rerum
lucretius knew it:
open the chest
and you will see that it’s full of swirling
snow.
and sometimes two flakes
meet, combine,
or else one turns aside gracefully
in its small death.
where does the idea come from that it’s clear
in a few words
when the one is only the night,
the other only a dream?
where do those two shadows come from
going along smiling,
and the one muffled up
in red wool?
translated_by_TA: Lucretius knew it: open the chest, you'll see, it's full of snow swirling around. And sometimes two snowflakes meet, unite, or one turns away, gracefully in its lack of death. Why is it that it's light in a few words when one is only night, the other only a dream? Where do these two shadows come from, walking, laughing, one wrapped in red wool?

original_poem:
juste avant l’aube
je regarde à travers les vitres, et je crois comprendre
qu’il a cessé de neiger. une flaque bleue
s’étend, brillante un peu, devant les arbres,
d’une paroi à l’autre de la nuit.
je sors.
je descends précautionneusement l’escalier de bois
dont les marches sont nivelées par la neige fraîche.
le froid cerne et pénètre mes chevilles,
il semble que l’esprit en soit plus clair,
qui perçoit mieux le silence des choses.
dort-il encore
dans l’enchevêtrement du tas de bois
serré sous la fenêtre,
le chipmunk, notre voisin simple,
ou est-il déjà à errer dans les crissements et le froid?
je vois d’infimes marques devant la porte.
translated_poem:
just before dawn
just before dawn
i look through the window, and i think i understand
that it has stopped snowing. a blue puddle
spreads, sparkling a little, in front of the trees,
from one end to the other of the night.
i go out.
i cautiously go down the wooden stairs
where the fresh snow has levelled the steps.
the cold surrounds and penetrates my ankles,
it seems that my mind is clearer because of it,
which perceives better the silence of things.
he is still sleeping
in the confusion of the pile of wood
ricked under the window,
the chipmunk, our simple neighbour,
or is he already roaming in the crunchy cold?
i see tiny marks in front of the door.
translated_by_TA:
Just before dawn
I look through the windows, and I think I understand
that it has stopped snowing. A blue puddle
spreads, glistening a little, in front of the trees,
from one wall of the night to the other.
I go outside.
I cautiously descend the wooden staircase
whose steps are leveled by fresh snow.
The cold surrounds and penetrates my ankles,
it seems that my mind is clearer,
which better perceives the silence of things.
Is he still asleep
in the tangle of the pile of wood
tightly packed under the window,
the chipmunk, our simple neighbor,
or is he already wandering in the creaking and the cold?
I see tiny marks in front of the door.

original_poem:
l’été encore
j’avance dans la neige, j’ai fermé
les yeux, mais la lumière sait franchir
les paupières poreuses, et je perçois
que dans mes mots c’est encore la neige
qui tourbillonne, se resserre, se déchire.
neige,
lettre que l’on retrouve et que l’on déplie,
et l’encre en a blanchi et dans les signes
la gaucherie de l’esprit est visible
qui ne sait qu’en enchevêtrer les ombres claires.
et on essaye de lire, on ne comprend pas
qui s’intéresse à nous dans la mémoire,
sinon que c’est l’été encore; et que l’on voit
sous les flocons les feuilles, et la chaleur
monter du sol absent comme une brume.
translated_poem:
summer again
i go through the snow. i closed
my eyes, but the light can still get through
my porous eyelids, and i perceive
that in my words it’s still the snow
that swirls, thickens, bursts.
snow,
a letter that we find and unfold,
and the ink on it has faded and in the marks
the clumsiness of the wit is visible
which can only muddle up its sharp shadows.
and we try to read, we don’t understand
who is interested in us in memory,
except that it’s summer again; and we see
under the flakes the leaves, and the heat
rise from the missing sun like a mist.
translated_by_TA:
summer again
I walk through the snow, I have closed
my eyes, but the light knows how to penetrate
the porous eyelids, and I perceive
that in my words it is still the snow
that swirls, tightens, tears.
snow,
a letter that one finds and unfolds,
and the ink has whitened and in the signs
the clumsiness of the mind is visible
which only knows how to tangle the clear shadows.
and we try to read, we don't understand
who is interested in us in memory,
except that it is still summer; and that we see
beneath the flakes the leaves, and the heat
rising from the absent ground like a mist.

original_poem:
la charrue
cinq heures. la neige encore. j’entends des voix
à l’avant du monde.
une charrue
comme une lune au troisième quartier
brille, mais la recouvre
la nuit d’un pli de la neige.
et cet enfant
a toute la maison pour lui, désormais. il va
d’une fenêtre à l’autre. il presse
ses doigts contre la vitre. il voit
des gouttes se former là ou il cesse
d’en pousser la buée vers le ciel qui tombe.
translated_poem:
the plough
five o’clock. snow again. i hear voices
in the front of the world.
a plough
like a moon in the third quarter
shines, but the night
covers it with a layer of snow.
and this child
has the whole house to himself, from now on. he goes
from one window to another. he presses
his fingers against the glass. he sees
drops form where he stops
pushing the mist towards the falling sky.
translated_by_TA:
The plow
five o'clock. The snow still. I hear voices
at the front of the world.
A plow
shines like a moon in its third quarter, but covers it
at night with a fold of snow.
And this child
has the whole house to himself, now. He goes
from one window to another. He presses
his fingers against the glass. He sees
drops forming where he stops
pushing the mist towards the falling sky.

original_poem:
les pommes
et que faut-il penser
de ces pommes jaunes?
hier, elles étonnaient, d’attendre ainsi, nues
après la chute des feuilles,
aujourd’hui elles charment
tant leurs épaules
sont, modestement, soulignées
d’un ourlet de neige.
translated_poem:
the apples
and what must we think
of these yellow apples?
yesterday, they astonished, waiting like this, naked
after the leaves had fallen,
today they charm
as their shoulders
are modestly accented
with an edging of snow.
translated_by_TA:
Apples
and what should we think
of these yellow apples?
Yesterday, they were astonishing, waiting like this, naked
after the leaves had fallen,
today they are charming
so much so that their shoulders
are, modestly, highlighted
by a hem of snow.

original_poem:
neige
fugace sur l’écharpe, sur le gant
comme cette illusion, le coquelicot,
dans la main qui rêva, l’été passé
sur le chemin parmi les pierres sèches,
que l’absolu est à portée du monde.
pourtant, quelle promesse
dans cette eau, de contact léger, puisqu’elle fut,
un instant, la lumière! le ciel d’été
n’a guère de nuées pour entrouvrir
plus clair chemin sous des voûtes plus sombres.
circé
sous sa pergola d’ombres, l’illuminée,
n’eut pas de fruits plus rouges.
translated_poem:
snow
snow
fleeting on the scarf, on the glove
like this illusion, the poppy,
in the hand that dreamed, last summer
on the road among the dry stones,
that the absolute is within reach of the world.
however, what promise
in the delicate touch of this water, for it was,
for an instant, the light! the summer sky
has hardly any clouds to half open
a brighter way under dark vaults.
circé
under her pergola of shadows, the visionary,
had no redder fruit.
translated_by_TA:
neige
fugace sur l’écharpe, sur le gant
comme cette illusion, le coquelicot,
dans la main qui rêva, l’été passé
sur le chemin parmi les pierres sèches,
que l’absolu est à portée du monde.
pourtant, quelle promesse
dans cette eau, de contact léger, puisqu’elle fut,
un instant, la lumière! le ciel d’été
n’a guère de nuées pour entrouvrir
plus clair chemin sous des voûtes plus sombres.
circé
sous sa pergola d’ombres, l’illuminée,
n’eut pas de fruits plus rouges.

original_poem:
le peu d’eau
à ce flocon
qui sur ma main se pose, j’ai désir
d’assurer l’éternel
en faisant de ma vie, de ma chaleur,
de mon passé, de ces jours d’à présent,
un instant simplement: cet instant-ci, sans bornes.
mais déjà il n’est plus
qu’un peu d’eau, qui se perd
dans la brume des corps qui vont dans la neige.
translated_poem:
the little bit of water
this snowflake
that alights on my hand, i wish
to fix it as eternal
in making of my life, my heat,
my past, these present days,
simply a moment, this very moment, limitless.
but already it is only
a little bit of water getting lost
in the mist of the flakes going into the snow.
translated_by_TA:
the little water
in this snowflake
that lands on my hand, I desire
to ensure the eternal
by making of my life, of my warmth,
of my past, of these days of now,
just an instant: this instant, without limits.
but already it is
no more than a little water, which is lost
in the mist of bodies going through the snow.

original_poem:
le jardin
il neige.
sous les flocons la porte
ouvre enfin au jardin
de plus que le monde.
j’avance. mais se prend
mon écharpe à du fer
rouillé, et se déchire
en moi l’étoffe du songe.
translated_poem:
the garden
it’s snowing.
under the snowflakes the gate
finally opens to the garden
of more than the world.
i go forward. but my scarf
gets caught on rusty
iron and tears
in me the fabric of the dream.
translated_by_TA:
The garden
It's snowing.
Under the snowflakes, the door
finally opens to the garden
of more than the world.
I advance. But my scarf gets caught on rusty iron, and the fabric of dreams within me is torn.

original_poem:
la grande neige
première neige tôt ce matin. l’ocre, le vert
se réfugient sous les arbres.
seconde, vers midi. ne demeure
de la couleur
que les aiguilles de pins
qui tombent elles aussi plus dru parfois que la neige.
puis, vers le soir,
le fléau de la lumière s’immobilise.
les ombres et les rêves ont même poids.
un peu de vent
écrit du bout du pied un mot hors du monde.
translated_poem:
the big snow
first snow early this morning. the ochre, the green
take refuge under the trees.
second, around noon. no colour
remains
except the pine needles
that sometimes fall thicker than the snow.
then toward evening,
the curse of the light comes to an end.
shadows and dreams have the same weight.
a little wind
writes with the tip of its toe a word outside the world.
translated_by_TA:
The deep snow
First snow early this morning. Ochre, green
take refuge under the trees.
Second, around noon. All that remains of color are the pine needles
which also fall sometimes thicker than the snow.
Then, towards evening,
the scourge of light stops.
Shadows and dreams have the same weight.
A little wind
writes with the tip of its foot a word beyond the world.

original_poem:
les fileuses
celle qui malgré l’hiver a gardé
aux joues le souvenir des raisins
suit de l’œil un couple lent ;
il franchit le pont de pierre
vers le bout de forêt où s’embusque
l’ombre bleue des renards. tout cela
prend silencieusement sa part de haine,
a l’heure où les jeunes femmes
quittent la maison lourde de neige,
la tête dans la nuit, étourdies d’avoir
bu du vin en flammes et filé le lin
de leurs draps entre les jeux, les gages
et les mensonges, sous le regard
des hommes qui graissaient des courroies.
translated_poem:
the spinners
the one who has kept, in spite of winter
a memory of grapes on her cheeks
follows a slow couple with her eyes;
they cross the stone bridge towards
a bit of forest where the blue shadows
of foxes lie in ambush. all that
silently claims its portion of hate,
at the hour when young women
leave the house, heavy with snow,
their heads still full of night, careless from having
drunk mulled wine and spun
the linen of their sheets between games, forfeits
and lies, beneath the gaze
of men waxing harnesses.
translated_by_TA:
The spinners
the one who, despite the winter, has kept
on her cheeks the memory of the grapes
follows with her eyes a slow-moving couple;
they cross the stone bridge
toward the edge of the forest where the blue shadows of the foxes lie in wait. All this
silently takes on its share of hatred,
at the hour when the young women
leave the house heavy with snow,
their heads in the night, dizzy from having
drank flaming wine and spun the flax
from their sheets between games, forfeits
and lies, under the gaze
of the men greasing the belts.

original_poem:
le moulin
je suis le point unique, la leçon
d’un paysage où se joignent, le soir,
rivière, église et vieux moulin :
le clocher monte, l’arbre tient,
la roue travaille, et l’eau grise
s’en va sous le vent d’hiver,
laissant passer, entre chaque aube,
de quoi moudre le grain, scier
les planches des cercueils, et faire
rêver l’oisif, dans ce roulement calme
qui continue à fabriquer de l’énergie
avec le temps qui reste à la matière
quand les hommes ont fini de crier
sur le manteau doux de la neige.
translated_poem:
the mill
i am the single point, the lesson
in a landscape where evening links
a stream, a church, and an old mill:
the bell tower rises, the tree stands fast,
the wheel works, and gray water
flows away beneath the winter wind,
letting enough pass, from dawn to dawn
to grind grain, to saw
coffin planks, to make
idle men dream, in this calm rumbling
which keeps on fabricating energy
in the time that’s left for matter
when mankind has done shouting
over the soft cloak of snow.
translated_by_TA:
the mill
I am the single point, the lesson
of a landscape where, in the evening,
river, church, and old mill come together:
the steeple rises, the tree stands,
the wheel works, and the gray water
goes away in the winter wind,
letting pass, between each dawn,
enough to grind grain, saw
the coffin boards, and make
the idler dream, in this calm tumbling
that continues to create energy
with the time left to matter
when men have finished shouting
on the soft blanket of snow.

original_poem:
conte
un soir où nous avions mis une seule ceinture
tu me chuchotais un conte à l’oreille de neige
et me disais je suis émue
et nous avions enjambé déjà plusieurs grands intervalles
fait des arches d’absence plus grandes que celles d’avignon
et sommes revenus à nous par des gués en crue
translated_poem:
tale
one evening as we were wearing a single belt
you whispered a tale in my ear of snow
and said i’m moved
and we had already stridden over several wide intervals
made of arches of absence wider than those at avignon
and came back to ourselves by rising fords
translated_by_TA:
story
one evening when we had only one belt on
you whispered a story in my snowy ear
and said to me I am moved
and we had already spanned several large gaps
made arches of absence larger than those of Avignon
and came back to ourselves by flooded fords

original_poem:
un arbre…
un arbre et puis un arbre et puis
le froid
je ne veux plus que cet aveugle
me guide
comme on est seul
quand on marche depuis toujours
un arbre et puis
pas même un arbre, une distance
d’autres, je les aimais,
sont loin.
translated_poem:
a tree
a tree and then a tree and then
the cold
i don’t want that blind one
to guide me anymore
how alone one is
when one has been walking from the outset
a tree and then
not even a tree, remote
others i loved, are far,
they are far.
translated_by_TA:
A tree...
A tree and then a tree and then
the cold
I no longer want this blind man
to guide me
as one is alone
when one has always walked
A tree and then
Not even a tree, a distance
Others, I loved them,
are far away.
